Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Expectation2: Communicate and offer small mutual help like receiving packages or checking in during emergencies
Situation2: A delivery is expected this afternoon while I will be at home and the neighbor often misses packages.
Story:
This afternoon, I was sitting at home, scrolling through my phone, when my sister called. Her voice trembled—she’d just had a rough argument with her boss and needed someone to talk to. As her brother, I knew she counted on me to listen, to be there for her when things got tough. I promised I’d call her back in a few minutes, just as the doorbell rang. It was my neighbor, Mrs. Lee, looking anxious. She explained she was expecting an important package today, but had to rush out for an emergency. She asked if I could keep an eye out and sign for it if it arrived.

I nodded, but inside, I felt the pressure mounting. My sister needed my full attention and support, but Mrs. Lee was counting on me too. If I got caught up on the phone, I might miss the delivery, and she’d be disappointed. If I focused on the door, I might not be the brother my sister needed right now. I stood in my hallway, phone in hand, heart pounding, torn between being the supportive brother and the reliable neighbor, unsure which role to put first.
